position.marginalia_text: Benedictus igitur sit illo, cuius dispositio sit ha[e]c, qui mortificat et viuificat, et omnipotens est [etc]

marginalia.translation: He may be blessed by the one whose disposition is that, who ends and makes live and is omnipotent.

position.marginalia_text: Et vlterius ista desiccatio, sive dispositio continuè fiet eius conversio in caliditatis natura[m], quod est in rubedine[m], qua[e] tame[n] provenit ex paucitate nigrificandi. Hoc idem dicit Rosinus, cum dicit quod ars MARTHEK, no[n] fit nisi ex STAGNO: ex quibus p[o]t[est] intelligi quod vnus est dispositor Albi, nigri, citrini et rubei [etc]

marginalia.translation: Subsequently the desiccation or disposition performs a continuous conversion into the nature of heat, that is, into redness, which however stems from a mild whitening. This is precisely what Rosinus [=Zosimos of Panopolis] means when saying that the art of the Marthek does not come about except from the Stagno. From this it can be seen that one is the dispositor of white, black, citrine and red.

position.marginalia_text: similiter coloris et candoris solis et luna[e]

marginalia.translation: Similarly of the colour and the radiance of the son and the moon.

position.marginalia_text: Et istud est tertiu[m] punctum artis secundu[m] Hermete[m], cum dicit, Tertio mense operatur Mars, agens in materia ex sua caliditate, et siccitate dividit et sequestrat ip[s]am massa[m], et me[m]bra disponit. Notetis membra. Nam sicut in matrice Natura

marginalia.translation: And this is the third point of the art according to Hermes. He says: In the third month Mars acts upon the matter, and divides with its heat and dryness that same mass and arranges its members. Note the word members. For just as in the womb, nature [...].
